questions.text: In Embryological development what causes release of testosterone from testes
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hcg from placenta During embryological development, the release of testosterone from the fetal testes is primarily stimulated by human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), which is secreted by the placenta. This hormone mimics the action of luteinizing hormone (LH), binding to LH receptors on the Leydig cells in the developing testes. The Leydig cells then produce testosterone, which is crucial for the development of the male internal and external genitalia. This testosterone surge is particularly important between the 8th and 12th weeks of gestation, during the critical period of sexual differentiation. Without this stimulation, male differentiation would not proceed correctly, even in an XY fetus. Since the fetal pituitary is not yet fully functional during early development, hCG serves as the key signal for Leydig cell stimulation and testosterone secretion. Incorrect Options: A. LH from mother – Incorrect: Maternal LH does not cross the placental barrier in significant amounts. Moreover, fetal Leydig cells are not dependent on maternal LH for stimulation, especially during early development. Instead, hCG from the placenta takes on this role. C. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus – Incorrect: While GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus eventually stimulates the fetal anterior pituitary to secrete LH and FSH later in development, this axis is not sufficiently active during the early stages when testosterone production is first needed for male differentiation. D. Inhibin from corpus luteum – Incorrect: Inhibin is involved in feedback regulation of FSH and is produced by Sertoli cells in males and granulosa cells in females. It does not stimulate testosterone production and has no direct role in activating Leydig cells in the fetal testes.

questions.text: Which type of hymen is shown in the image below
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Septate A septate hymen is characterized by a thin band of extra hymenal tissue that runs vertically or horizontally across the vaginal opening, creating two distinct openings instead of one. This condition results from incomplete resorption of the central hymenal tissue during fetal development. The septum can vary in thickness and length. Although often asymptomatic, a septate hymen may cause issues with tampon insertion or intercourse and can be corrected with a minor surgical procedure. When visualized, it clearly shows a membrane dividing the vaginal orifice into two separate openings, which is diagnostic for a septate hymen and distinguishes it from other hymenal anomalies. Incorrect Options: B. Annular – Incorrect: An annular hymen has a single central opening and is the most common type of hymen. It does not have any septum or extra tissue dividing the opening, so it would not appear divided like in the image showing a septate hymen. C. Imperforate hymen – Incorrect: This is a condition where the hymenal membrane completely covers the vaginal opening, with no visible opening at all. It typically presents in adolescence with primary amenorrhea and cyclic pelvic pain due to obstructed menstrual flow. The image in question shows openings, which rules this out. D. Cribriform hymen – Incorrect: A cribriform hymen has multiple small perforations or holes throughout the hymenal membrane, giving it a sieve-like appearance. This is different from the two large distinct openings seen in a septate hymen.

questions.text: Contraception of choice for 18months postpartum woman who is breast feeding having heavy and irregular bleeding
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Mala N The most appropriate contraceptive choice for an 18-month postpartum woman who is breastfeeding and experiencing heavy and irregular bleeding is Mala N, a low-dose combined oral contraceptive pill (COC) containing ethinyl estradiol and norethisterone acetate. At 18 months postpartum, breastfeeding is typically less frequent, and the estrogen in COCs is less likely to affect milk production significantly. Mala N not only provides effective contraception but also helps regulate menstrual cycles and reduce menstrual blood loss, which is particularly beneficial for women experiencing heavy and irregular bleeding. Its use is safe after 6 months postpartum in breastfeeding women and is recommended in such clinical scenarios. Incorrect Options: A. Norethisterone enanthate depot injection – Incorrect: This is a progestin-only injectable contraceptive, which is suitable for breastfeeding women, but it may worsen menstrual irregularities and is often associated with unpredictable bleeding patterns, making it less ideal for a woman already struggling with heavy and irregular bleeding. B. Progestasert – Incorrect: Progestasert is a progesterone-releasing intrauterine device, but it is not commonly used anymore and requires replacement annually. Moreover, it may not sufficiently control heavy bleeding compared to other options and is generally not preferred when menstrual regulation is a key concern. D. Copper T – Incorrect: While Copper T (a non-hormonal intrauterine device) is safe in breastfeeding women, it is associated with increased menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea, which would likely worsen the current symptom of heavy bleeding.

choices.text: Post molar evacuation after trophoblastic disease

questions.text: COPPER T contraindicated in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Post molar evacuation after trophoblastic disease The Copper T intrauterine device (IUD) is contraindicated post molar evacuation due to the risk of persistent gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) or choriocarcinoma. Following a molar pregnancy, close monitoring of serum beta-hCG levels is essential to ensure complete resolution and detect any malignant transformation. Inserting an IUD during this period could mask symptoms of persistent disease (such as abnormal bleeding) and increase the risk of uterine perforation or infection in an already unstable uterine environment. Therefore, Copper T is contraindicated until hCG levels have normalized and remained stable for a period, confirming complete remission. Incorrect Options: A. Ruptured condom during intercourse – Incorrect: This situation calls for emergency contraception, and Copper T can actually be used as an emergency contraceptive if inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse. It is highly effective and not contraindicated here. B. Menstruation – Incorrect: Copper T can be safely inserted during menstruation. In fact, insertion during menstruation is often preferred because the cervix is naturally dilated, and it is easier to rule out pregnancy at this time. D. Immediate delivery – Incorrect: Copper T can be inserted immediately postpartum (within 10 minutes of placental delivery), known as postpartum IUD insertion. It is considered safe and effective when proper aseptic techniques are used.

questions.text: 22 year old female presents with infertility. HSG was done what is your diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Septate uterus The correct diagnosis is septate uterus, a common congenital uterine anomaly that results from incomplete resorption of the Müllerian ducts’ central septum during embryogenesis. On hysterosalpingography (HSG), a septate uterus typically appears as a single uterine cavity with a central filling defect or indentation, often creating a triangular or “V”-shaped endometrial cavity. This condition is the most common uterine anomaly associated with infertility, early miscarriage, and poor pregnancy outcomes because the fibrous septum lacks adequate blood supply for implantation. The good news is that it is correctable by hysteroscopic septum resection, which can significantly improve fertility outcomes. Incorrect Options: A. Bicornuate uterus – Incorrect: This arises from incomplete fusion of the Müllerian ducts, resulting in a uterus with two horns. On HSG, it appears as a widely spaced, heart-shaped cavity with a broader angle between the endometrial contours (>105°), unlike the narrow angle seen in a septate uterus. It is less commonly associated with infertility than a septate uterus. B. Uterus didelphys – Incorrect: This anomaly results from complete failure of Müllerian duct fusion, leading to two separate uterine cavities and often two cervices. HSG shows two completely separate endometrial cavities with no communication. It's more likely to present with reproductive loss than primary infertility. C. Unicornuate uterus – Incorrect: This results from complete failure of one Müllerian duct to develop, creating a single, small, banana-shaped uterine cavity. HSG shows a long, narrow cavity deviated to one side. While it can be associated with poor reproductive outcomes, it is not the typical appearance of a septate uterus on imaging.

choices.text: Abstinence for 3 weeks avoid pregnancy for 2 years
Abstinence for 3 months avoid pregnancy for 1 year
Abstinence for 6 weeks avoid pregnancy for 6 years
Abstinence for 6 months avoid pregnancy for 1 year

questions.text: Recommendation after surgery for VVF
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Abstinence for 3 months, avoid pregnancy for 1 year Following surgical repair of a vesicovaginal fistula (VVF), the recommended advice is to maintain sexual abstinence for at least 3 months to allow proper healing of the repaired tissue and prevent breakdown of the surgical site. Additionally, pregnancy should be avoided for 1 year, as pregnancy and particularly labor and delivery can place strain on the healing tissues and potentially lead to recurrence of the fistula. This 1-year period allows sufficient time for complete tissue remodeling and strengthens the repair. Patients should also be counseled on appropriate contraception to prevent unintended pregnancy during this healing phase. Incorrect Options: A. Abstinence for 3 weeks, avoid pregnancy for 2 years – Incorrect: Three weeks is too short a duration for vaginal healing post VVF repair, and two years of avoiding pregnancy is unnecessarily long unless there are specific complications. C. Abstinence for 6 weeks, avoid pregnancy for 6 years – Incorrect: While 6 weeks may be sufficient for some postoperative recoveries, it is not adequate for VVF repair, and avoiding pregnancy for 6 years is excessive and not evidence-based. D. Abstinence for 6 months, avoid pregnancy for 1 year – Incorrect: While the 1-year pregnancy avoidance is appropriate, 6 months of abstinence is longer than necessary and can negatively impact quality of life and relationships without added benefit, unless medically indicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an emergency contraception?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Danazol Danazol is not used as an emergency contraceptive. It is a synthetic androgen derived from 17-alpha-ethinyl testosterone, primarily used in the management of endometriosis, fibrocystic breast disease, and hereditary angioedema. Its mechanism involves suppression of the pituitary-ovarian axis, reducing gonadotropin secretion and subsequently estrogen production. However, Danazol does not act quickly enough nor effectively inhibit ovulation or implantation in the narrow window required for emergency contraception. Additionally, its androgenic side effects (such as weight gain, acne, and hirsutism) make it unsuitable for this purpose. Incorrect Options: B. CuT 200 – Incorrect: Copper IUDs like CuT 200 are among the most effective emergency contraceptive methods. When inserted within 5 days of unprotected intercourse, they prevent fertilization by causing a spermicidal inflammatory reaction in the uterine environment. They can also inhibit implantation if fertilization has already occurred. C. RU486 (Mifepristone) – Incorrect: Mifepristone is a progesterone receptor antagonist and can be used in low doses (10–25 mg) as an emergency contraceptive. It works by delaying ovulation and making the endometrium unsuitable for implantation if taken in the early luteal phase. D. High dose Estrogen – Incorrect: High-dose estrogen, either alone or in combination with progestin (Yuzpe regimen), has been historically used for emergency contraception. Though less common today due to side effects like nausea and vomiting, it remains a recognized method by altering the endometrium and preventing implantation.

questions.text: First line of Rx of osteoporosis in post menopausal women:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bisphosphonates Bisphosphonates are the first-line treatment for osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. They work by inhibiting osteoclast-mediated bone resorption, thereby increasing bone mineral density (BMD) and reducing the risk of fractures, particularly vertebral, non-vertebral, and hip fractures. Commonly used bisphosphonates include alendronate, risedronate, and zoledronic acid. They are widely recommended due to their proven efficacy, good safety profile, and affordability. Oral bisphosphonates are generally taken weekly or monthly, while intravenous formulations can be given annually or quarterly, depending on the specific drug and patient needs. Incorrect Options: A. Estrogen – Incorrect: Estrogen therapy can prevent bone loss in postmenopausal women, but it is not first-line due to the associated risks, such as increased incidence of breast cancer, thromboembolism, and cardiovascular events. It is generally reserved for women who also need hormone replacement therapy for menopausal symptoms. C. Raloxifene – Incorrect: Raloxifene is a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) that mimics estrogen's effects on bone. While it helps in reducing vertebral fracture risk, it is less effective than bisphosphonates and does not reduce hip fracture risk. It is considered in women who cannot tolerate bisphosphonates or are at lower fracture risk but need added breast cancer protection. D. Ulipristal – Incorrect: Ulipristal acetate is a selective progesterone receptor modulator used primarily for emergency contraception and fibroid management. It has no role in the treatment of osteoporosis, making it entirely unrelated in this context.

questions.text: Which of the following is not estrogen dependent pubertal change:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hair growth Hair growth during puberty, specifically pubic and axillary hair, is not dependent on estrogen but is primarily regulated by androgens (mainly from the adrenal glands). This process is part of adrenarche, which is a separate event from gonadarche (ovarian estrogen production). Adrenal androgens like DHEA and DHEAS are responsible for stimulating the development of pubic and axillary hair, and this change can occur even in the absence of ovarian function or estrogen production. Therefore, hair growth is not an estrogen-dependent change, making option A the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B. Menstruation – Incorrect: Menstruation is a hallmark of estrogen activity and occurs only after sufficient endometrial proliferation under the influence of estrogen, followed by progesterone and subsequent withdrawal. It is a clearly estrogen-dependent pubertal milestone. C. Vaginal cornification – Incorrect: Estrogen stimulates squamous epithelial proliferation and cornification (keratinization) of the vaginal mucosa. In prepubertal girls with low estrogen, the vaginal epithelium remains thin and atrophic. Thus, this is an estrogen-mediated change. D. Cervical mucus – Incorrect: The quality and quantity of cervical mucus are highly responsive to estrogen levels. Estrogen increases watery, stretchy, and sperm-friendly mucus, especially around ovulation. This change is directly estrogen-dependent.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Bilateral Hydrosalpinx The image shows bilateral hydrosalpinx, which is characterized on hysterosalpingography (HSG) by dilated, tortuous fallopian tubes filled with contrast material that demonstrate distension of the tubes with a characteristic "sausage-shaped" or elongated appearance. The contrast outlines the dilated tubes but fails to spill freely into the peritoneal cavity due to blockage at the fimbrial end, confirming tubal obstruction with fluid accumulation. Bilateral involvement suggests pathology affecting both fallopian tubes, which is often due to pelvic inflammatory disease, tuberculosis, or previous pelvic surgery and is a known cause of infertility. Incorrect Options: A. Normal HSG – Incorrect: A normal HSG shows smooth, slender fallopian tubes with free spillage of contrast into the peritoneal cavity, indicating patent tubes. The presence of dilated and tortuous tubes with no free spillage clearly rules out normal findings. C. Bilateral Cornual Block – Incorrect: Cornual block appears as failure of contrast to pass beyond the uterine cornu (the proximal part of the fallopian tubes) with no filling of the tubes distal to the blockage. The image shows dilated tubes rather than non-filling or abrupt blockage near the uterine end, which excludes cornual block. D. None – Incorrect: Since the features clearly demonstrate bilateral hydrosalpinx, this option is not applicable.

questions.text: The instrument used in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Laparoscopic sterilization The instrument in question is typically a laparoscopic tubal ligation device, such as laparoscopic bipolar forceps or clip applicators. These instruments are used during laparoscopic sterilization to occlude or seal the fallopian tubes, thereby preventing fertilization. Laparoscopic sterilization is a minimally invasive procedure where small incisions and specialized instruments allow the surgeon to visualize and block the tubes using clips, rings, or electrocoagulation. The instruments are specifically designed for precision in manipulating and sealing the delicate tubal structures. Incorrect Options: B. Removal of ectopic pregnancy – Incorrect: Although laparoscopic instruments are used in ectopic pregnancy removal, the instrument shown is most characteristic of tubal sterilization procedures. Ectopic removal typically involves graspers, scissors, and suction devices rather than specialized tubal occlusion instruments. C. Myomectomy – Incorrect: Myomectomy involves removal of uterine fibroids and requires instruments such as laparoscopic morcellators, scissors, and electrosurgical tools, not instruments designed for tubal occlusion. D. Endometrial polypectomy – Incorrect: Endometrial polypectomy is performed hysteroscopically using a resectoscope or hysteroscopic instruments, not laparoscopic instruments.

questions.text: Identify the image:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Female condom The image shows a female condom, which is a soft, loose-fitting sheath made of polyurethane or nitrile that lines the inside of the vagina. It has two flexible rings: an inner ring that is inserted into the vagina to hold the condom in place around the cervix, and an outer ring that remains outside the vaginal opening, covering the vulva. The female condom acts as a barrier method of contraception, preventing sperm from entering the uterus and also providing protection against sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Incorrect Options: B. Male condom – Incorrect: A male condom is a thin sheath that fits snugly over the erect penis and is usually made of latex or polyurethane. It does not have two rings and is not inserted into the vagina, making this option inconsistent with the image. C. Cervical cap – Incorrect: A cervical cap is a small, cup-shaped device made of silicone or latex that fits tightly over the cervix. It does not have an external ring and is much smaller than a female condom. D. Diaphragm – Incorrect: A diaphragm is a dome-shaped, flexible latex or silicone device that covers the cervix and is used with spermicide. It also lacks the outer ring characteristic of the female condom and fits snugly against the vaginal walls.

questions.text: A 35yrs old female attends gynaec OPD with h/o excessive bleeding since 6 months not controlled with non hormonal drugs USG and clinical examination reveal no abnormality. Next step is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hormonal therapy In a woman of reproductive age with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) but no structural abnormalities detected on ultrasound or clinical examination, the most appropriate next step is to initiate hormonal therapy. Hormonal treatment, typically with combined oral contraceptives or progestins, helps regulate the menstrual cycle, reduce bleeding, and stabilize the endometrium. This approach is effective in managing functional causes of AUB, such as anovulatory bleeding or hormonal imbalance, which are common in this age group. Incorrect Options: A. Endometrial sampling – Incorrect: Although endometrial sampling is important in cases of suspected endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, it is usually reserved for women over 40 years old or those with risk factors such as obesity, prolonged bleeding, or failed medical management. In a 35-year-old with normal imaging and no risk factors, immediate sampling is not always necessary. B. Endometrial ablation – Incorrect: Endometrial ablation is a treatment option for heavy menstrual bleeding but is generally considered only after failure of medical management and once structural causes have been ruled out thoroughly. It is also typically reserved for women who have completed childbearing. D. Hysterectomy – Incorrect: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is invasive and reserved for refractory cases after medical and less invasive surgical options have failed or in cases of significant pathology such as fibroids or malignancy. It is not the initial step in a young woman without abnormal findings.

questions.text: A mother brings her 16 yrs old daughter to gynaec OPD with complaints of not attaining menarche. She gives h/o cyclical abdominal pain. On farther examination midline abdominal swelling seen. Par rectal examination reveals bulging mass in vagina. Which of the following do you suspect?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Imperforate hymen The clinical picture described is classic for imperforate hymen. This congenital anomaly results in a membranous obstruction at the vaginal opening, preventing menstrual blood from exiting the body. Consequently, the patient experiences primary amenorrhea despite having normal ovarian function, and develops cyclical abdominal pain due to accumulation of menstrual blood in the vagina (hematocolpos) and sometimes uterus (hematometra), which may present as a midline lower abdominal swelling. The bulging mass seen on per rectal examination corresponds to the distended vagina filled with retained blood pushing forward, causing visible or palpable bulging at the vaginal introitus. Incorrect Options: B. Transverse vaginal septum – Incorrect: A transverse vaginal septum also causes obstruction to menstrual flow but is located higher up in the vaginal canal, not at the hymenal level. It often leads to similar symptoms but on examination, the vagina is shorter and the bulging mass is not seen at the introitus, making imperforate hymen more likely here. C. Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome – Incorrect: MRKH syndrome is characterized by vaginal agenesis or hypoplasia and uterine agenesis or hypoplasia, leading to primary amenorrhea without cyclical abdominal pain, as there is no menstruation or blood accumulation. There would be no bulging vaginal mass or abdominal swelling. D. Vaginal agenesis – Incorrect: Vaginal agenesis involves absence or severe hypoplasia of the vagina. These patients present with primary amenorrhea but typically do not have cyclical pain or hematocolpos, since menstrual blood cannot accumulate without a functioning uterus or outflow tract.

questions.text: A 13yrs old child visits gynaec OPD with complaints of not attaining menarche with karyotype 46XX. On examination there is cliteromegaly. What enzyme likely to be deficient in the above condition:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 21-hydroxylase The most likely diagnosis is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency, the most common form of CAH. This enzyme deficiency leads to impaired cortisol and aldosterone synthesis, resulting in accumulation of steroid precursors, which are diverted to androgen synthesis. The excess androgens cause virilization of external genitalia in a 46XX individual, such as clitoromegaly, while internally the female reproductive organs remain normal. Additionally, the lack of cortisol leads to increased ACTH stimulation, worsening adrenal hyperplasia and androgen excess. This hormonal imbalance can delay menarche, leading to primary amenorrhea. Incorrect Options: B. 11-hydroxylase – Incorrect: 11β-hydroxylase deficiency can also cause androgen excess and virilization, but it is less common. It is more frequently associated with hypertension due to accumulation of 11-deoxycorticosterone (a mineralocorticoid), which is not mentioned in this case. The most typical and likely enzyme involved remains 21-hydroxylase. C. 17-hydroxylase – Incorrect: 17-hydroxylase deficiency causes decreased androgen and estrogen production, resulting in under-virilization or female phenotype in 46XY individuals, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics in 46XX. It is associated with hypertension and hypokalemia, and clitoromegaly would not be expected. D. 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase – Incorrect: This rare deficiency leads to defects in the synthesis of all three adrenal steroid classes (glucocorticoids, mineralocorticoids, and androgens). It typically presents with ambiguous genitalia in both sexes and salt-wasting crises, but clitoromegaly with isolated amenorrhea would be uncommon as a sole finding.

questions.text: Mrs Rekha having her child of 2 yrs of age presents to her family obstetrician with c/o pruritis vulvae, and amenorrhea. She gives h/o severe blood loss and failure of lactation during pregnancy. She is lethargic and has cold intolerance She has got multiple skin infectionsand anemia. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Sheehan’s Syndrome The clinical features are classic for Sheehan’s Syndrome, a form of hypopituitarism that occurs due to ischemic necrosis of the pituitary gland following severe postpartum hemorrhage. In this case, the woman had significant blood loss during childbirth, followed by failure to lactate (due to prolactin deficiency) and amenorrhea (due to gonadotropin deficiency). Other symptoms like lethargy, cold intolerance, recurrent infections, and anemia suggest deficiency of multiple anterior pituitary hormones, including TSH, ACTH, and GH. The absence of pituitary hormones leads to secondary hypothyroidism, adrenal insufficiency, and hypogonadism, explaining the full constellation of signs and symptoms. Incorrect Options: B. Asherman Syndrome – Incorrect: This condition is characterized by intrauterine adhesions, usually following uterine curettage or infection, leading to secondary amenorrhea. However, it does not cause systemic symptoms like cold intolerance, anemia, skin infections, or failure of lactation. C. Prolactinomas – Incorrect: These are pituitary tumors secreting prolactin, typically causing galactorrhea and amenorrhea. However, they do not cause failure of lactation or systemic hormonal deficiencies. Also, pruritus vulvae and cold intolerance are not typical features. D. None – Incorrect: The symptoms clearly point toward an endocrine disorder secondary to postpartum hemorrhage. “None” would be incorrect because Sheehan’s syndrome fully explains all the clinical features.

questions.text: A sexually active female came with profuse frothy foul smelling discharge with intense itching. O/e strawberry cervix revealed. What condition she suffer?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichomonas vaginalis The described symptoms and findings are classic for Trichomoniasis, caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It is a sexually transmitted infection (STI). The profuse, frothy, greenish-yellow discharge with a foul odor and intense itching are hallmark symptoms. A distinctive clinical sign is the “strawberry cervix”, which results from punctate hemorrhages on the cervix due to the inflammatory response caused by the parasite. Diagnosis is often confirmed via wet mount microscopy, which shows motile trichomonads. Incorrect Options: B. Candidiasis – Incorrect: Vaginal candidiasis typically presents with thick, white, curd-like (“cottage cheese”) discharge and intense itching, but not frothy or foul-smelling discharge. There is no strawberry cervix, and the cervix generally appears normal. C. Bacterial vaginosis – Incorrect: BV is associated with thin, greyish-white, fishy-smelling discharge, especially after intercourse. There is no significant itching, and no inflammation or strawberry cervix. It is caused by an overgrowth of anaerobic bacteria, not an STI. D. None – Incorrect: The presentation clearly points to Trichomonas vaginalis, which is a well-known and common cause of such symptoms. “None” is incorrect as a specific diagnosis (Trichomoniasis) is supported by clinical features.

questions.text: A 26 yrs old with married life of 2 years visits infertility clinic. She was put on HMG. On treatment she developed Dyspnea, abdominal pain Her USG reports shows following image. What is the condition called?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) The clinical presentation is classic for Ovarian Hyperstimulation Syndrome (OHSS), a potentially serious complication of fertility treatment, particularly when using gonadotropins like HMG. OHSS occurs due to exaggerated ovarian response to stimulation, resulting in enlarged ovaries with multiple cysts, increased vascular permeability, fluid shift into third spaces, and symptoms such as abdominal pain, bloating, ascites, and dyspnea. Severe OHSS may even lead to pleural effusion, hemoconcentration, and thromboembolic events. Ultrasound typically shows bilaterally enlarged ovaries with multiple thin-walled cysts, consistent with what is expected in this scenario. Incorrect Options: A. Theca lutein cysts – Incorrect: While these cysts also appear as bilateral ovarian cysts, they are typically associated with high hCG states like molar pregnancy or multiple gestation, not directly with HMG use. They are less likely to cause systemic symptoms like dyspnea and ascites unless very large. C. PCOD (Polycystic Ovarian Disease) – Incorrect: PCOD is a chronic condition associated with irregular cycles, anovulation, and hyperandrogenism. The ovaries appear slightly enlarged with a “string of pearls” appearance on ultrasound, but PCOD does not present acutely with symptoms like dyspnea or abdominal pain, nor is it a complication of ovulation induction therapy. D. None – Incorrect: The symptoms and imaging findings clearly align with OHSS. “None” is an inappropriate choice as a specific and well-recognized diagnosis (OHSS) fits this clinical scenario.

questions.text: A 18 years old girl comes to gynecology OPD presenting with 6 months of amenorrhea, with h/o low grade fever, weight loss, pain abdomen, generalized weakness. On clinical examination, pelvic mass felt on left side with features of ascites. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TB pelvis with tubo-ovarian mass The most likely diagnosis is pelvic tuberculosis (TB) with a tubo-ovarian mass, which is common in young women, particularly in regions where TB is endemic. The combination of chronic amenorrhea, low-grade fever, weight loss, pelvic pain, and a mass with ascites is strongly suggestive of genital TB. Tuberculous infection of the genital tract often involves the fallopian tubes, ovaries, and endometrium, leading to the formation of tubo-ovarian masses. Ascites and constitutional symptoms like fever and weight loss are classic signs. Genital TB can also cause infertility and menstrual disturbances including amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea. Incorrect Options: B. Ectopic pregnancy – Incorrect: Though ectopic pregnancy can present with amenorrhea and abdominal pain, it is more acute, and typically associated with positive pregnancy test, vaginal bleeding, and hemodynamic instability in case of rupture. Fever, weight loss, or ascites are not features of ectopic pregnancy. C. Granulosa cell tumour – Incorrect: This is a rare ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor that may present with hyperestrogenism, leading to precocious puberty or abnormal uterine bleeding, not typically amenorrhea. While it can form a pelvic mass, constitutional symptoms like fever and weight loss are not typical. D. Fibroid with degeneration – Incorrect: Degenerating fibroids may cause pelvic pain and a mass, but are usually found in older reproductive-age women, not adolescents. They do not typically cause fever, weight loss, ascites, or amenorrhea.

choices.text: Small bowel is most radio resistant
Small blood vessels are most radio resistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radio resistant
Dost/intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of distance of the source

questions.text: A 55 years old women diagnosed to be Ca cervix stage 2B advised for chemoradiation. Which of the following is true statement?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Dose/intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of distance of the source This is a fundamental principle in radiation physics known as the inverse square law. It states that the intensity (or dose) of radiation decreases with the square of the distance from the radiation source. In practical terms, if you double the distance from the radiation source, the dose received becomes one-fourth. This principle is crucial in radiation therapy planning, as it helps ensure the tumor receives an adequate dose while minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissues. This law applies universally to point sources of radiation and is a key factor in delivering safe and effective chemoradiation treatment for cancers such as cervical cancer. Incorrect Options: A. Small bowel is most radioresistant The small bowel is actually one of the more radiosensitive organs in the abdomen and pelvis. It has rapidly dividing cells in the mucosal lining, which makes it vulnerable to radiation-induced damage such as enteritis. Radiosensitivity is higher in tissues with rapid cell turnover, so the small bowel’s tolerance to radiation is relatively low compared to more radioresistant tissues. B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant Small blood vessels, especially capillaries, can be damaged by radiation because the endothelial cells lining these vessels are moderately radiosensitive. Radiation can cause inflammation, fibrosis, and vascular damage leading to ischemia in tissues. Large blood vessels tend to be more resistant, but small vessels are not the most radioresistant structures. C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant In fact, rapidly proliferating cells are generally more radiosensitive, not radioresistant. Radiation primarily damages DNA, and cells that are actively dividing (such as cancer cells or cells in the bone marrow and mucosa) are more susceptible to radiation damage because they have less time to repair DNA damage before mitosis. Slowly dividing or non-dividing cells tend to be more radioresistant.

questions.text: Remnants of wolffian duct are located in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Broad ligament Remnants of the Wolffian duct (also called mesonephric duct) in females are typically found in the broad ligament. During embryonic development, the Wolffian ducts mostly regress in females but some remnants persist and can be found as small vestigial structures in the broad ligament, such as Gartner’s ducts or cysts. These remnants can sometimes give rise to Gartner’s duct cysts in adults. The broad ligament is the peritoneal fold that supports the uterus and connects it to the lateral pelvic walls, providing a typical anatomical location for these Wolffian duct remnants. Incorrect Options: A. POD (Pouch of Douglas) The pouch of Douglas, or rectouterine pouch, is a peritoneal space between the posterior wall of the uterus and the rectum. It is not a location for Wolffian duct remnants. The pouch of Douglas is a common site for fluid collection or endometriosis, but not for mesonephric duct remnants. B. Lower part of vagina The lower part of the vagina develops from the urogenital sinus, not from the Wolffian duct. Wolffian duct remnants are not found here. Instead, the vagina forms from the fusion of the Müllerian ducts (upper part) and the urogenital sinus (lower part). D. Uterovesical pouch The uterovesical pouch is the peritoneal space between the uterus and the bladder. Like the pouch of Douglas, this space is not known to contain remnants of the Wolffian duct. It serves as a potential space for fluid accumulation but does not contain embryological remnants of the mesonephric duct.

questions.text: Meiosis occurs in
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Adult ovary Meiosis in females primarily occurs in the adult ovary, beginning during fetal life but arresting at prophase I until puberty. After puberty, during each menstrual cycle, some oocytes resume meiosis and proceed to metaphase II, where they arrest again until fertilization. Thus, active meiosis occurs in the adult ovary during the process of oocyte maturation and ovulation. This meiotic division is crucial for producing haploid gametes (ova) with half the chromosome number for sexual reproduction. Incorrect Option: A. Prepubertal testes In males, meiosis does not occur in the prepubertal testes. Although testes contain spermatogonia, meiosis only begins at puberty when spermatogenesis starts. Before puberty, spermatogonia remain dormant and do not enter meiosis. Therefore, meiosis is absent in prepubertal testes.

questions.text: The distention media used in hysteroscopy with bipolar cautery is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Normal Saline (NS) In hysteroscopy procedures using bipolar cautery, normal saline (NS) is the preferred distention medium. This is because bipolar electrosurgical devices require an electrically conductive fluid to allow safe and effective energy delivery. Normal saline is isotonic, non-electrolyte-disturbing, and conductive, making it suitable for bipolar energy use. Using NS reduces the risk of electrolyte imbalance or fluid overload complications that can occur with other media. Incorrect Options: A. CO2 Carbon dioxide gas can be used as a distention medium in diagnostic hysteroscopy, but it is generally not used when electrosurgery is planned because gas does not conduct electricity. This makes CO2 unsuitable for procedures involving cautery. C. Dextran 70 Dextran 70 is a viscous, non-electrolyte fluid sometimes used as a distention medium but is less commonly preferred due to risks of allergic reactions and fluid overload. Additionally, its viscosity makes it less ideal for use with bipolar cautery. D. Glycine Glycine is a non-conductive, hypotonic fluid used with monopolar electrosurgery to avoid electrical conduction through the fluid. However, it is not recommended with bipolar cautery because bipolar devices work safely with conductive fluids like saline. Glycine use also carries the risk of hyponatremia and fluid absorption complications.

questions.text: Most common complication expected in partial transverse vaginal septum with history of pelvic pain
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Endometriosis In cases of partial transverse vaginal septum, menstrual blood can accumulate behind the obstruction, leading to retrograde menstruation. This backward flow of menstrual blood into the pelvic cavity is a key factor in the development of endometriosis, where endometrial tissue implants outside the uterus causing pelvic pain, adhesions, and infertility. Therefore, endometriosis is the most common complication expected in a patient with a partial transverse vaginal septum presenting with pelvic pain. Incorrect Options: A. Tuboovarian abscess A tuboovarian abscess usually results from pelvic inflammatory disease and is characterized by infection and pus formation in the fallopian tubes and ovaries. While it can cause pelvic pain, it is not directly related to the obstructive pathology seen in vaginal septum. C. Dermoid cyst Dermoid cysts (mature cystic teratomas) are benign ovarian tumors arising from germ cells. They are unrelated to vaginal septal anomalies and do not typically cause pelvic pain due to obstruction or menstrual outflow issues. D. Theca lutein cyst Theca lutein cysts are functional ovarian cysts caused by high levels of human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG), often seen in molar pregnancy or multiple gestations. They are not associated with vaginal septa or menstrual obstruction.

questions.text: Patient having primary infertility with bilateral cornual block due to intramural fibroid one is 5*7 cm and other 3*5cm. Husband semen analysis normal. Ovary normal. What is the best management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Laparoscopic myomectomy In a patient with primary infertility and bilateral cornual block caused by intramural fibroids (one measuring 5×7 cm and the other 3×5 cm), the best management is laparoscopic myomectomy. Intramural fibroids, especially of this size, can distort the uterine cavity or the fallopian tube ostia, causing tubal blockage and infertility. Surgical removal of fibroids (myomectomy) can restore normal uterine anatomy and tubal patency, improving chances of natural conception. Laparoscopic myomectomy is preferred over open surgery due to faster recovery and fewer adhesions, which is beneficial for fertility. Incorrect Options: A. ART (Assisted Reproductive Technology) ART, such as IVF, may bypass tubal factors but is generally considered after surgical correction of structural abnormalities like fibroids. Using ART without correcting mechanical causes of infertility like fibroids may reduce success rates and increase complications. C. GnRH analogue GnRH analogues can reduce fibroid size temporarily but do not cure the fibroids or restore tubal patency. They are typically used preoperatively to shrink fibroids before surgery, but not as a sole treatment in infertility cases with tubal blockage. D. UAE (Uterine Artery Embolization) UAE is a nonsurgical treatment to shrink fibroids by cutting off their blood supply. However, it is generally contraindicated in women desiring fertility because it may impair uterine and ovarian function and negatively affect fertility outcomes.

choices.text: Multiple dose methotrexate with folinic acid

questions.text: 26 year old patient with post molar evacuation with cannon ball metastasis and irregular vaginal bleeding what is management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Multiple dose methotrexate with folinic acid A 26-year-old patient with a history of molar pregnancy evacuation presenting with cannon ball metastases (suggesting lung metastasis) and irregular vaginal bleeding indicates high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). The preferred initial management in such cases is multi-dose methotrexate with folinic acid rescue or alternatively multi-agent chemotherapy depending on the risk scoring. Multiple-dose methotrexate with folinic acid is effective in high-risk patients to control disease progression and minimize toxicity. Folinic acid (leucovorin) rescue reduces methotrexate toxicity while maintaining its efficacy. Incorrect Options: A. EMACO EMACO (Etoposide, Methotrexate, Actinomycin D, Cyclophosphamide, and Vincristine) is a multi-agent chemotherapy regimen typically reserved for very high-risk or resistant GTN cases. While effective, it is more toxic and usually not the first-line therapy unless multi-dose methotrexate fails or the patient has ultra-high-risk features. B. Single dose methotrexate Single dose methotrexate is used for low-risk GTN patients without metastases or minimal disease. In the presence of metastases such as cannon ball lesions, single dose therapy is insufficient and ineffective. C. Hysterectomy Hysterectomy is generally not the first line of treatment in metastatic GTN since chemotherapy is highly effective. Surgery may be reserved for cases with uncontrollable bleeding or localized resistant disease but is not the primary treatment in metastatic cases.

questions.text: Management of uterine septum
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hysteroscopic septoplasty The management of a uterine septum, which is a congenital malformation characterized by a fibrous or muscular partition dividing the uterine cavity, is best performed by hysteroscopic septoplasty. This minimally invasive procedure involves resecting the septum via the hysteroscope, allowing restoration of a normal uterine cavity without external incisions. Hysteroscopic septoplasty is preferred because it has a high success rate in improving fertility and pregnancy outcomes, shorter recovery time, and fewer complications compared to open surgeries. Incorrect Options: B. Uterine metroplasty Uterine metroplasty generally refers to an open surgical procedure to correct uterine anomalies. While effective, it is more invasive and associated with longer recovery times and higher risk of complications compared to hysteroscopic surgery, making it less favorable for uterine septum correction today. C. Laparoscopic resection Laparoscopy may be used to assist in diagnosing uterine anomalies or to evaluate the external contour of the uterus but is not the primary approach to resect a uterine septum since the septum is inside the uterine cavity and best accessed hysteroscopically. D. Laparotomy metroplasty This is an open abdominal surgery and is largely outdated for uterine septum correction. It is associated with increased morbidity and is reserved for very rare complex cases where hysteroscopic surgery is not feasible.

questions.text: Condition not associated with uterine didelphius
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Transverse lie Uterine didelphys is a congenital uterine anomaly characterized by complete failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts, resulting in two separate uterine horns, each with its own endometrium and cervix. While uterine didelphys is associated with reproductive complications such as abortion and preterm labor, it is not typically associated with transverse lie. The presence of two separate uteri allows enough space for the fetus to position normally in most cases, so transverse lie is uncommon. Incorrect Options: A. Abortion Recurrent miscarriage or abortion is a common complication in uterine didelphys due to the smaller uterine cavity size and potential poor implantation environment in one or both horns. B. Preterm Preterm labor and delivery are frequently observed in uterine didelphys cases because of limited uterine capacity and cervical insufficiency, leading to early onset of labor. D. Endometriosis Endometriosis can be associated with uterine anomalies including uterine didelphys due to retrograde menstruation or altered pelvic anatomy, making this option a possible associated condition.

choices.text: Discontinue and take different method of contraception
Take all 4 pills together contiue drugs and take barrier method for 7 days
Continue same packet, use barrier and consider emergency pill if intercourse in last 72 hrs

questions.text: Patient comes with missing 4 OCPs on different days twice in last 2 weeks next advise
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Continue same packet, use barrier and consider emergency pill if intercourse in last 72 hrs When a patient misses multiple oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) — in this case, 4 pills on different days twice within 2 weeks — the best advice is to continue the same pack without stopping, use a barrier method (like condoms) for the next 7 days as additional protection, and consider emergency contraception if unprotected intercourse has occurred within the last 72 hours. This approach maintains contraceptive coverage without unnecessary interruption, reduces risk of pregnancy, and addresses the risk from recent unprotected intercourse. Prompt use of emergency contraception (like levonorgestrel) can help prevent pregnancy if needed. Incorrect Options: A. Discontinue and take different method of contraception Stopping OCPs abruptly and switching methods is not necessary after missed pills. The priority is to maintain hormonal contraception by continuing the current pack and adding backup protection rather than abandoning the method. B. Take all 4 pills together, continue drugs and take barrier method for 7 days Taking multiple missed pills all at once is not recommended, as it can increase side effects such as nausea and does not improve contraceptive efficacy. It is better to take the most recent missed pill as soon as possible and continue daily pills regularly. C. Continue same packet Simply continuing the same packet without additional precautions is insufficient after missing multiple pills on different days, as the risk of ovulation and pregnancy increases. Backup barrier contraception and emergency contraception consideration are important.

questions.text: What is investigation being done
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) HSG HSG (Hysterosalpingography) The investigation being referred to is most likely Hysterosalpingography (HSG), which is an X-ray procedure used to evaluate the uterine cavity and fallopian tube patency. It involves injecting a radio-opaque contrast dye through the cervix and taking images to see if the dye passes freely through the fallopian tubes into the peritoneal cavity. HSG is the first-line investigation in infertility workup to assess tubal blockage and uterine abnormalities, making it the most appropriate and commonly performed investigation in such cases. Incorrect Options: B. Laparoscopy Laparoscopy is a surgical procedure involving insertion of a camera into the abdomen to directly visualize pelvic organs. While it can assess tubal status and pelvic pathology, it is invasive and usually reserved for cases where HSG findings are abnormal or when endometriosis or adhesions are suspected. C. Hysteroscopy Hysteroscopy involves direct visualization of the uterine cavity using a scope inserted through the cervix. It is useful to evaluate and treat intrauterine pathology but does not assess tubal patency. Hence, it is not the initial investigation for tubal evaluation. D. Normal saline hysterogram A saline infusion sonohysterogram (normal saline hysterogram) involves injecting sterile saline into the uterine cavity during transvaginal ultrasound to evaluate uterine contour and cavity. It helps detect intrauterine lesions but does not assess fallopian tubes, making it less suitable than HSG for tubal patency assessment.

questions.text: What is the best to identify Mullerian anomalies
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Laparoscopy + hysteroscopy The best way to identify Müllerian anomalies is by combining laparoscopy and hysteroscopy. This combined approach allows direct visualization of both the external uterine contour (via laparoscopy) and the uterine cavity (via hysteroscopy). Since Müllerian anomalies involve abnormalities in uterine shape, cavity, and external morphology, using both methods provides comprehensive and accurate diagnosis. Laparoscopy identifies external contour differences (e.g., bicornuate vs septate uterus), while hysteroscopy examines the endometrial cavity for septa or duplications. Incorrect Options: A. HSG (Hysterosalpingography) HSG provides a 2D outline of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes but cannot reliably differentiate between external uterine contour anomalies like bicornuate and septate uterus. Thus, it is limited in accurately classifying Müllerian anomalies. B. USG (Ultrasonography) Ultrasound, especially 2D USG, can screen for uterine anomalies but lacks detail in defining the uterine shape and external contour. Even 3D ultrasound, though improving accuracy, might not replace direct visualization for definitive diagnosis. D. Laparoscopy Laparoscopy alone visualizes the external surface of the uterus but cannot evaluate the endometrial cavity, which is crucial to diagnose cavity abnormalities like septa. Hence, it is incomplete alone for full assessment of Müllerian anomalies.

questions.text: Lady with history of urination on coughing with cystocele
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI) The patient with a history of urination on coughing along with a cystocele is most likely experiencing Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI). SUI occurs due to weakness or damage to the pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter, which causes urine leakage during increased intra-abdominal pressure activities like coughing, sneezing, or lifting. The presence of a cystocele (prolapse of the bladder into the vaginal wall) further weakens bladder support, exacerbating SUI. Incorrect Options: B. Overflow incontinence Overflow incontinence is characterized by constant dribbling due to an overfilled bladder and incomplete emptying, often caused by bladder outlet obstruction or neurogenic bladder. It is not typically triggered by coughing or physical exertion. C. Urge incontinence Urge incontinence involves a sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by involuntary leakage, often due to detrusor overactivity. Leakage related to coughing is not a feature of urge incontinence. D. Neurogenic bladder Neurogenic bladder refers to bladder dysfunction caused by neurological disorders affecting bladder control. Symptoms can vary widely, but leakage on coughing is more characteristic of SUI than neurogenic bladder.

questions.text: All of the following is true about low dose progesterone except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Totally stops ovulation Low dose progesterone, such as in some contraceptive methods, does not totally stop ovulation. While progesterone can suppress ovulation to some extent, it is not completely reliable in doing so at low doses. In fact, ovulation sometimes still occurs despite low dose progesterone. This is why other mechanisms like cervical mucus changes and endometrial alterations are important for contraception with low dose progesterone. Incorrect Options: B. Causes changes in luteal phase Low dose progesterone can cause subtle alterations in the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, such as shortening or making it less optimal for implantation. This effect contributes to its contraceptive action. C. Causes change in cervical mucus One of the primary contraceptive effects of low dose progesterone is thickening of cervical mucus, which inhibits sperm penetration and fertilization, making this a true and important mechanism. D. Sometimes ovulation occurs It is correct that with low dose progesterone, ovulation sometimes still happens because suppression is not absolute, which contrasts with higher dose combined contraceptives that more reliably prevent ovulation.

questions.text: A 30 years-old women visited the doctor with the complaint of infertility, following test was done showing given abnormality, what is the diagnosis-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Unicornuate uterus A unicornuate uterus is a Müllerian duct anomaly resulting from incomplete development of one of the paired ducts, leading to a single uterine horn with a small or absent second horn. It is often associated with infertility and recurrent pregnancy loss due to reduced uterine volume and abnormal shape. Imaging or diagnostic tests reveal a solitary, asymmetric uterine structure with one fallopian tube, consistent with this diagnosis. Incorrect Options: B. Septate uterus A septate uterus has a normal external uterine contour but an internal fibrous or muscular septum dividing the uterine cavity. It typically presents with infertility or pregnancy losses but differs from unicornuate uterus by the presence of a single uterus externally. C. Didelphous uterus Didelphous uterus is characterized by two separate uterine horns, each with its own endometrium and cervix, resulting from complete failure of fusion of the Müllerian ducts. It shows two symmetric uterine bodies, unlike the unilateral structure seen in unicornuate uterus. D. Bicornuate uterus Bicornuate uterus results from partial fusion failure of the Müllerian ducts, creating two horns with a single cervix. It shows a heart-shaped uterus with two horns, contrasting with the single horn of the unicornuate uterus.

questions.text: Fimbriectomy is associated with-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Kroener Fimbriectomy, the surgical removal of the fimbrial end of the fallopian tube, is most commonly associated with the Kroener technique. This procedure is used primarily in cases of hydrosalpinx before assisted reproductive techniques like IVF, to improve fertility outcomes by removing diseased fimbrial segments that could affect embryo implantation. Incorrect Options: A. Parkland The Parkland technique refers to a surgical method primarily associated with cesarean section incision or other gynecologic procedures but is not related to fimbriectomy. B. Irwin Irwin's technique is mainly related to abdominal hysterectomy procedures and does not pertain to fimbriectomy. C. Uchida Uchida’s procedure generally refers to techniques involving tubal surgery or reconstructive procedures but is not specifically linked to fimbriectomy.

questions.text: A women presented with abnormal vaginal bleeding. A gross section of her uterus given is shown below diagnosis is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Leiomyoma The gross section of the uterus showing a well-circumscribed, firm, and whorled appearance is characteristic of leiomyoma (uterine fibroid). Leiomyomas are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus and a common cause of abnormal vaginal bleeding in women of reproductive age. They often appear as multiple nodules within the uterine wall and can distort the uterine cavity, leading to menorrhagia or irregular bleeding. Incorrect Options: B. Cervical polyp Cervical polyps are benign growths protruding from the cervical canal and would not be seen as a mass in the uterine wall on a gross uterine section. They typically cause spotting or post-coital bleeding but do not alter the gross uterine architecture. C. Endometrial carcinoma Endometrial carcinoma involves the lining of the uterus and presents as a thickened, friable, or ulcerated endometrium rather than a well-circumscribed firm mass. Grossly, it does not have the whorled appearance typical of leiomyoma. D. Metastasis Metastatic lesions to the uterus are rare and typically present as multiple nodules or diffuse infiltration rather than a solitary, well-defined mass. The gross appearance usually differs significantly from a benign leiomyoma.

questions.text: Anteversion of uterus is maintained by?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Round and uterosacral ligament Anteversion of the uterus refers to the forward tilt of the uterine body over the cervix. This position is primarily maintained by the round ligaments and the uterosacral ligaments. The round ligaments provide anterior support by pulling the uterus forward, while the uterosacral ligaments provide posterior support, stabilizing the uterus in anteverted position and preventing excessive backward movement. Incorrect Options: B. Cardinal ligament The cardinal (transverse cervical) ligament mainly supports the uterus laterally and anchors the cervix to the pelvic sidewall, but it does not play a primary role in maintaining anteversion. C. Pubocervical and round ligament The pubocervical ligament supports the anterior vaginal wall and cervix but is more involved in preventing cystocele than maintaining uterine position. The round ligament does contribute to anteversion, but pubocervical ligament alone cannot maintain it. D. Pubocervical and uterosacral ligament While the uterosacral ligament supports the uterus posteriorly, the pubocervical ligament mainly supports the anterior vaginal wall and does not play a direct role in maintaining uterine anteversion.

choices.text: 46 XX with testes and ovaries and gynaecomastia

questions.text: Testiovo syndrome (previously called as true hermaphrodite) is characterized by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 46 XX with testes and ovaries and gynecomastia Testiovo syndrome, previously referred to as true hermaphroditism, is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual. These may exist as separate gonads (one ovary and one testis) or as ovotestes (a single gonad containing both tissues). Most individuals have a 46,XX karyotype, though mosaicism (e.g., 46,XX/46,XY) can also be seen. Clinically, patients may present with ambiguous genitalia, gynecomastia, and infertility. This condition reflects disorders of sexual development (DSDs) and is distinct from syndromes involving only gonadal dysgenesis or chromosomal aneuploidy. Incorrect Options: A. 45 XO with streak gonads This describes Turner syndrome, a condition characterized by gonadal dysgenesis, where the ovaries are replaced by non-functional streak tissue. These individuals do not have both testicular and ovarian tissue, and typically present with primary amenorrhea and short stature. C. 45 XXY with testes This refers to Klinefelter syndrome, where individuals have male external genitalia and testes but typically suffer from hypogonadism, infertility, and gynecomastia. They do not have ovarian tissue, making this inconsistent with Testiovo syndrome. D. 45 XX with streak ovary This is not a typical karyotype and likely reflects a variant or error. Streak ovaries are associated with Turner syndrome (usually 45,XO), not with the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue. Thus, this option does not fit the description of Testiovo syndrome.

questions.text: In congenital adrenal hyperplasia what is seen?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Female Pseudohermaphroditism Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of autosomal recessive disorders caused by enzyme deficiencies involved in cortisol biosynthesis, most commonly 21-hydroxylase deficiency. This enzyme block leads to cortisol deficiency and excess androgen production. In a 46,XX (genetic female) fetus, the internal reproductive organs (ovaries, uterus, fallopian tubes) develop normally, but due to androgen excess, the external genitalia become virilized or ambiguous. This condition is called female pseudohermaphroditism, where the individual is genetically and gonadally female but has masculinized external genitalia. It is one of the most well-known examples of this condition and may present with clitoromegaly, fused labia, and sometimes a urogenital sinus. Incorrect Options: A. Male hermaphroditism This term is outdated and not well-defined. It may be mistakenly used to describe individuals with ambiguous genitalia, but in CAH, the affected individuals are typically genetic females (46,XX), not males. B. Female hermaphroditism This historically referred to individuals with both ovarian and testicular tissue (now called ovotesticular DSD or true hermaphroditism). CAH does not involve the presence of testicular tissue, so this term is incorrect in the context of CAH. C. Male pseudohermaphroditism This refers to individuals with a 46,XY (genetic male) karyotype who have underdeveloped or ambiguous external genitalia due to androgen insufficiency (e.g., androgen insensitivity syndrome or 5-alpha reductase deficiency). Since CAH typically affects 46,XX individuals who are virilized, this term does not apply.

questions.text: All of the following is seen in chronic PID except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pyometra uterus Pyometra, or pus collection within the uterine cavity, is not commonly associated with chronic Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). Pyometra is more typically seen in elderly, postmenopausal women, often due to cervical stenosis or malignancy that blocks the outflow tract. While acute PID may cause endometritis, chronic PID more commonly leads to tubal and peritoneal damage rather than intrauterine pus accumulation. Therefore, pyometra is not a typical finding in chronic PID, making this the correct answer. Incorrect Options: B. Ectopic pregnancy Chronic PID often results in tubal damage and adhesions, impairing the transport of the fertilized ovum. This increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy, particularly in the fallopian tube, due to distorted anatomy and impaired ciliary function. C. Infertility Infertility is a well-known long-term consequence of chronic PID. The condition causes tubal occlusion, adhesions, and peritoneal damage, all of which interfere with gamete transport and implantation. D. Tubal defect Chronic inflammation in PID leads to tubal scarring, blockage, and hydrosalpinx, which are collectively referred to as tubal defects. These are key pathological features of chronic PID and major contributors to infertility and ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: Most common sequelae of chronic PID?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Infertility Infertility is the most common sequela of chronic Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID). Chronic PID causes persistent inflammation and scarring of the fallopian tubes, leading to tubal obstruction, hydrosalpinx, and peritubal adhesions. These structural damages impair the movement of the ovum and sperm, making natural conception difficult or impossible. Even subclinical PID can lead to significant tubal pathology over time. Therefore, infertility is the most frequent and clinically significant long-term outcome of chronic PID. Incorrect Options: A. Ectopic pregnancy While ectopic pregnancy is a known complication of chronic PID due to damaged and dysfunctional fallopian tubes, it is less common than infertility. Tubal dysfunction increases the risk of embryo implantation outside the uterus, particularly in the fallopian tube, but this occurs less frequently than infertility. C. Pyometra uterus Pyometra (accumulation of pus in the uterus) is not commonly associated with PID, especially chronic PID. It is more typically seen in postmenopausal women with cervical stenosis or uterine malignancy. It is rare in reproductive-age women with PID. D. Endometrial cancer There is no direct link between chronic PID and endometrial cancer. While PID affects the upper genital tract, endometrial cancer is primarily associated with unopposed estrogen exposure, obesity, and age, not chronic inflammation due to PID.

choices.text: Two or more ova in same cycle from separate act of coitus~
Two or more ova different cycle~
Two or more ova same act of coitus

questions.text: Superfecundation is fertilisation of:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Two or more ova in same cycle from separate act of coitus Superfecundation refers to the fertilization of two or more ova released during the same menstrual cycle, but from separate acts of coitus, possibly involving different sperm donors. This can occur because sperm can survive up to 5 days in the female reproductive tract, and ovulation may release more than one ovum. If intercourse occurs on different days around ovulation, each ovum can be fertilized by sperm from different acts of intercourse, leading to non-identical (dizygotic) twins. When different partners are involved, it is called heteropaternal superfecundation. Incorrect Options: B. Two or more ova different cycle This describes superfetation, not superfecundation. Superfetation is an extremely rare phenomenon where a second ovulation and fertilization occur during an already ongoing pregnancy, typically from a different menstrual cycle. C. Two or more ova same act of coitus This situation still leads to dizygotic twins, but if both ova are fertilized from the same act of intercourse, it is not superfecundation. Superfecundation specifically involves separate acts of intercourse. D. Single ova splitting into two This describes monozygotic (identical) twinning, where one fertilized ovum splits into two embryos. It is not related to superfecundation, which involves multiple ova and typically leads to dizygotic (non-identical) twins.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common reason to use HRT?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Hot flushes Hot flushes (also called hot flashes) are the most common and most bothersome symptom of menopause, and therefore the most common reason for initiating Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT). They are caused by fluctuating and ultimately declining estrogen levels, which affect the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center. HRT, particularly estrogen therapy, is highly effective in alleviating vasomotor symptoms like hot flushes and night sweats. It provides rapid symptom relief and significantly improves the quality of life in symptomatic postmenopausal women. Incorrect Options: B. Vaginal atrophy While HRT is effective in treating urogenital atrophy (vaginal dryness, irritation, dyspareunia), this is not the most common reason for starting systemic HRT. In fact, local vaginal estrogen preparations are often preferred over systemic therapy for isolated urogenital symptoms. C. Headaches Headaches are not an indication for HRT. In fact, HRT may worsen migraines in some women due to hormonal fluctuations. Headaches are managed based on their etiology, and HRT is not typically considered a treatment option. D. Abnormal vaginal bleeding This is not an indication for HRT and must be investigated thoroughly, especially in postmenopausal women, as it could be a sign of endometrial pathology (e.g., hyperplasia or cancer). HRT may actually cause or exacerbate bleeding if not properly balanced with progestin in women with an intact uterus.

questions.text: MullerianInhibiting substance gene is located in which chromosome?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chromosome 19 The Müllerian Inhibiting Substance (MIS), also known as Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH), is a glycoprotein responsible for the regression of the Müllerian ducts during male embryonic development. The gene encoding MIS, known as AMH gene, is located on chromosome 19p13.3. This gene is expressed by Sertoli cells of the fetal testes and plays a crucial role in male sex differentiation by preventing the development of female internal reproductive structures such as the uterus, fallopian tubes, and upper part of the vagina. Incorrect Options: B. Chromosome 21 Chromosome 21 is best known for its association with Down syndrome (trisomy 21). It does not house the AMH gene and has no direct role in sexual differentiation or Müllerian duct regression. C. X Chromosome Although several genes related to reproduction and ovarian development are located on the X chromosome, the AMH gene is not one of them. Disorders involving the X chromosome, such as Turner syndrome, affect ovarian development differently and are unrelated to MIS production. D. Y Chromosome The Sex-determining Region Y (SRY) gene, which initiates male differentiation by triggering testis development, is located on the Y chromosome. However, the AMH gene itself is not located on the Y chromosome, though its expression is influenced by testis development induced by Y-linked genes.

questions.text: All are advantage of hysteroscopic over open myomectomy except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Recurrence Recurrence is not an advantage of hysteroscopic myomectomy over open myomectomy. In fact, the recurrence rate may be higher with hysteroscopic procedures, especially if the fibroids are not completely removed or if there are multiple fibroids. Hysteroscopic myomectomy is primarily used for submucosal fibroids, and if the fibroid extends deep into the myometrium, complete resection may not be feasible, leading to a greater chance of recurrence compared to open (abdominal) myomectomy, where fibroids are more thoroughly excised. Incorrect Options: A. Less pain Hysteroscopic myomectomy is a minimally invasive procedure performed through the vaginal route without abdominal incisions. As a result, it causes significantly less postoperative pain compared to open surgery. B. Early ambulation Since it is a non-invasive approach, recovery is faster, allowing earlier mobilization and discharge from the hospital. This is a clear advantage over open myomectomy, which involves a longer recovery period. D. Less bleed Hysteroscopic procedures are associated with less intraoperative blood loss compared to open surgeries. The use of electrosurgical instruments and smaller surgical field contributes to better hemostasis.

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasms does not include
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Partial mole Partial mole is not included under Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN). It is a type of gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) but not neoplastic in nature. Most partial moles are benign and do not invade surrounding tissues or metastasize. GTN, on the other hand, includes malignant and invasive forms of trophoblastic disease that may require chemotherapy or more intensive treatment. Partial moles are typically managed by evacuation and followed with β-hCG monitoring, but they very rarely progress to GTN. Incorrect Options: A. Choriocarcinoma Choriocarcinoma is a highly malignant form of GTN. It arises from any type of pregnancy and is characterized by aggressive invasion and metastasis, often requiring systemic chemotherapy. B. Placental site trophoblastic tumour (PSTT) PSTT is a rare variant of GTN arising from intermediate trophoblasts at the placental implantation site. It has a slow-growing but potentially invasive course and may not respond well to chemotherapy, often requiring surgical management. C. Invasive mole An invasive mole is a neoplastic transformation of a hydatidiform mole that penetrates the myometrium and sometimes beyond. It is considered a form of GTN and typically responds well to chemotherapy.

questions.text: 45 year old female with 3 months of menorrhagia. USG showing 2 cm fibroid. What is the treatment of choice
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Endometrial sampling In a 45-year-old woman presenting with menorrhagia and a uterine fibroid, it is essential to rule out endometrial pathology, especially endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, as abnormal bleeding in this age group can be a sign of underlying premalignant or malignant conditions. Even though a 2 cm fibroid may contribute to bleeding, endometrial sampling is the first step to evaluate the cause of menorrhagia before starting treatment. This ensures appropriate management based on histopathology. Incorrect Options: A. OCP for 3 months Oral contraceptive pills may be used for menstrual regulation and bleeding control in younger women or those without suspicious endometrial pathology. However, in a perimenopausal woman with new menorrhagia, starting OCPs without ruling out endometrial abnormalities is not recommended. B. Progesterone for 3 months Progesterone therapy can help in cases of anovulatory bleeding or endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. But, similar to OCPs, starting treatment without confirming the endometrial status is inappropriate in this context. D. Hysterectomy Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment for fibroids causing menorrhagia, but it is too aggressive as an initial step without proper evaluation. Surgery is generally reserved for patients who have failed medical management or have confirmed pathology requiring definitive intervention.

questions.text: In low ovarian reserve, the anti Mullerian hormone levels will be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) <1 Anti-Müllerian Hormone (AMH) is a hormone secreted by granulosa cells of early developing ovarian follicles and is a reliable marker of ovarian reserve—the quantity of remaining follicles in the ovaries. In cases of low ovarian reserve, the number of follicles decreases, leading to a significant reduction in AMH levels, typically less than 1 ng/mL. Low AMH indicates diminished ovarian follicle pool and predicts a poor response to ovarian stimulation in fertility treatments. Incorrect Options: B. 4-7 AMH levels between 4 and 7 ng/mL suggest a normal to high ovarian reserve. This range is typically seen in women with good fertility potential and not in those with low ovarian reserve. C. 7-10 AMH levels in this range are considered above normal and may be seen in conditions such as polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), where ovarian follicle count is increased. D. More than 10 Extremely high AMH levels (above 10 ng/mL) strongly suggest PCOS or ovarian hyperstimulation risk and definitely not low ovarian reserve.

questions.text: 30 yr old women with complaints of dysmennorea, dyspareunia with chronic pelvic pain undergoes hysterectomy. From the cut section of hysterectomy specimen below, identify the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Adenomyosis Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial glands and stroma within the myometrium (the muscular wall of the uterus). This leads to a diffusely enlarged, boggy uterus, often described as a “globular uterus.” Clinically, it commonly presents in women aged 30-50 with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and dyspareunia, exactly as described in this case. On gross hysterectomy specimen, adenomyosis shows a thickened uterine wall with small cystic spaces or hemorrhagic foci within the myometrium due to ectopic endometrial tissue. Incorrect Options: B. Fibroid uterus Fibroids (leiomyomas) are benign smooth muscle tumors of the uterus that present as well-circumscribed, firm, round masses within the myometrium. They usually cause menorrhagia and pelvic pressure, but less commonly cause dyspareunia and chronic pelvic pain. On gross examination, fibroids appear as distinct nodules, unlike the diffuse changes seen in adenomyosis. C. Endometriosis Endometriosis refers to ectopic endometrial tissue located outside the uterus, commonly on the ovaries, pelvic peritoneum, or other pelvic structures. It does cause dysmenorrhea and pelvic pain but would not be diagnosed from the uterine cut section as it affects extrauterine sites. D. Ectopic pregnancy Ectopic pregnancy is the implantation of a fertilized ovum outside the uterine cavity, most often in the fallopian tube. It does not cause chronic pelvic pain or dysmenorrhea for months and would not be identified on a hysterectomy specimen as a uterine pathology.

choices.text: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair

questions.text: 60 yr old woman comes with 3 rd degree uterine prolapse. What will be the management?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair In a 60-year-old woman with third-degree uterine prolapse, the best management is vaginal hysterectomy combined with pelvic floor repair. Third-degree prolapse indicates the uterus has descended beyond the vaginal introitus, often causing symptoms like discomfort, urinary issues, and infections. Vaginal hysterectomy removes the prolapsed uterus, and pelvic floor repair (anterior and posterior colporrhaphy) restores the support structures to prevent recurrence. This combined approach addresses both the cause and the structural weakness, providing definitive treatment with good functional and anatomical outcomes. Incorrect Options: B. Pelvic floor repair Pelvic floor repair alone, without removing the prolapsed uterus, may not be adequate in third-degree prolapse, especially in postmenopausal women. The bulky prolapsed uterus often needs removal to relieve symptoms fully and reduce recurrence risk. C.
